Sri Mulyani: Anak-anak Lebih Minat Jadi Youtuber Daripada Menkeu
04 Nov 2019, 04:43 by Dias Prasongko, Rahma Tri
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Menteri Keuangan Sri Mulyani Indrawati hari ini menjadi guru relawan yang mengajar di Sekolah Dasar (SD) Kenari I, Kwitang, Jakarta Pusat. Dalam kesempatan itu, Sri Mulyani memberikan materi terkait keberagaman, negara Indonesia hingga pengelolaan keuangan negara.
Saat menyampaikan materi terkait pengelolaan keuangan negara, Sri Mulyani sempat melontarkan pertanyaan kepada siswa-siswi mengenai minat mereka menjadi Direktur Jenderal Pajak ataupun Menteri Keuangan. Menurut dia, kebanyakan siswa-siswi tersebut ternyata tak berminat.
"Ditanya mau jadi Dirjen Pajak, mau jadi Menteri Kuangan? Enggak mau mereka, mereka maunya jadi Youtuber, jadi atlet internasional, jadi pilot jadi pengusaha sukses," kata Sri Mulyani di Jakarta Pusat, Senin 4 November 2019.
Adapun, kedatangan Sri Mulyani untuk menjadi guru selama sehari merupakan bagian dari rangkaian acara "Peringatan Hari Oeang 2019" yang digelar Kementerian Keuangan. Dalam acara ini, Kementerian mengajak para pegawainya untuk menjadi relawan mengajar bagi anak-anak sekolah.
Kegiatan relawan dari Aparatur Sipil Negara (ASN) Kementerian Keuangan ini digelar secara serentak di Indonesia. Acara ini digelar di 27 provinsi dengan melibatkan 3.700 relawan pegawai Kementerian Keuangan. Acara ini diklaim tak menggunakan dana APBN namun menggunakan dana pihak yang menjadi relawan.
Sri Mulyani menilai anak-anak sekolah dasar tersebut ternyata mengetahui tentang pengelolaan keuangan negara. Salah satunya terkait penerimaan pajak. Menurut Sri Mulyani hal itu tampak saat anak-anak melakukan role playing atau permainan peran untuk mengelola keuangan negara.
"Yang paling mengesankan buat saya adalah mereka tahu. Waktu saya tanya, apakah kita mengumpulkan penerimaan dari pajak itu penting atau tidak penting" tutur Sri Mulyani.
Mantan Direktur Pelaksana Bank Dunia ini berujar, lewat permainan peran tersebut terlihat ada diskusi yang menarik terkait perlunya membayar pajak. Terdapat anak yang mengatakan tidak perlu membayar pajak, namun ternyata lebih banyak yang mengatakan perlu membayar pajak.
"Saya tanya kenapa kok kalian harus bayar? Ya, untuk kepentingan bersama, itu solidaritas yang luar biasa, keluar spontan dari mereka. Menurut saya, ini adalah satu pesan luar biasa," ujar Sri Mulyani.

Sri Mulyani: Children are More Interested in YouTubers than Minister of Finance
Nov 04 2019, 04:43 by Dias Prasongko, Rahma Tri
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Minister of Finance Sri Mulyani Indrawati today is a volunteer teacher who teaches at Kenari I Elementary School, Kwitang, Central Jakarta. On that occasion, Sri Mulyani provided material related to diversity, the Indonesian state to the management of state finances.
When delivering material related to the management of state finances, Sri Mulyani briefly raised questions to students about their interest in becoming Director General of Taxes or Minister of Finance. According to him, most of the students were apparently not interested.
"Asked that they want to be the Director General of Taxes, want to be the Minister of Finance? Don't want them, they want to be Youtubers, become international athletes, so pilots become successful entrepreneurs," Sri Mulyani said in Central Jakarta, Monday, November 4, 2019.
Meanwhile, the arrival of Sri Mulyani to become a teacher for a day is part of a series of events "Commemoration of Oeang 2019 Day" held by the Ministry of Finance. In this event, the Ministry invites its employees to become teaching volunteers for school children.
The volunteer activities of the Ministry of Finance's State Civil Service (ASN) were held simultaneously in Indonesia. The event was held in 27 provinces involving 3,700 volunteers from the Ministry of Finance. This event is claimed not to use state budget funds but to use funds from volunteers.
Sri Mulyani assessed that these elementary school children were aware of the management of state finances. One of them is related to tax revenue. According to Sri Mulyani, this was apparent when children were playing role playing to manage state finances.
"The most impressive thing for me is that they know. When I asked, whether we collect revenue from taxes is important or not important," said Sri Mulyani.
The former Managing Director of the World Bank said, through this role play there was an interesting discussion related to the need to pay taxes. There are children who say they do not need to pay taxes, but apparently more who say they need to pay taxes.
"I asked why why do you have to pay? Yes, for the common good, that is extraordinary solidarity, coming out spontaneously from them. In my opinion, this is an extraordinary message," Sri Mulyani said.
